metadata.case_name: Durgadas Shirali v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Petitioner Durgadas Shirali arrested on January 2, 1965 at Jaipur pursuant to detention order dated December 29, 1964 by District Magistrate of Bhilwara (Shri Narayan Das Mehta, Respondent No. 3).
Detention order under Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules, 1962, delegated by Government of Rajasthan Notification No. F.7/116 Home A.Cr.163 dated November 4, 1963.

Detention order states: Leftist wing of Communist Party carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda, preparing for widespread agitation to establish communist regime by subversion and violence; constitutes real danger to external and internal security; petitioner is Secretary of Leftist Wing at Bhilwara, likely to act prejudicial to Defence of India, Civil Defence, India's relations with foreign powers, public safety, maintenance of public order.
Order reviewed by Reviewing Authority on January 13, 1965, recommended confirmation.
State Government confirmed detention order by order No. F7/119 Home A-Cr.I/65 dated January 22, 1965.
District Magistrate's affidavit (para 3): Satisfied from reports that petitioner carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda as member of Leftist Wing.
District Magistrate's affidavit (para 5): Passed order after satisfying himself from reports that petitioner is Secretary of Leftist Wing, Bhilwara branch, likely to act prejudicially.

legal_issues.text: Whether District Magistrate applied his mind to specific activities of petitioner or made order solely based on activities of Leftist Wing of Communist Party.
Whether membership/Secretaryship of Leftist Wing of Communist Party (not declared illegal or banned) is relevant ground for detention under Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: District Magistrate did not apply mind to specific activities of petitioner; complete absence of material suggesting petitioner's conduct prejudicial; order mala fide and illegal.
Ground of membership/Secretary of Leftist Wing (not declared illegal or banned) irrelevant; no real/proximate connection to prejudicial activities.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Shibban Lal Saksena v. State of Uttar Pradesh

respondent_arguments.text: District Magistrate satisfied from reports of petitioner's anti-national pro-Chinese propaganda as member/Secretary of Leftist Wing; applied mind to specific facts.

court_reasoning.text: Presidential Orders under Art. 359(1) bar challenges based on Arts. 14,19,21,22 but not mala fides or irrelevant grounds/lack of nexus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petition challenges on other grounds like mala fides and irrelevance, outside purview of Presidential Orders.

court_reasoning.text: DM's affidavit shows satisfaction from reports on petitioner's specific activities (propaganda as member/Secretary); not solely party activities.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot accept no application of mind.

court_reasoning.text: Membership/political association relevant; open to consider reports on associations/loyalties; close/proximate connection to security/public order under Rule 30.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Activities not illegal per se merely because party not banned; relevant consideration.

holdings.text: Detention order valid; petitioner failed to show mala fides, non-application of mind, or irrelevant grounds.
Political association/membership of Leftist Wing relevant under Rule 30(1)(b); has proximate nexus to security/public order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Legal effect of Emergency Proclamation and Presidential Orders under Art. 359(1); bars challenges on Arts.14,19,21,22 but not mala fides/irrelevant grounds.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shibban Lal Saksena v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioner relied on for irrelevant grounds vitiating detention; court holds party membership relevant despite not banned.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition under Art.32; Emergency suspends Art.19 (Art.358); Presidential Orders bar certain fundamental rights challenges (Art.359).

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Rules, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order; authorizes detention if likely prejudicial to defence, etc.

outcome.summary: Petition for habeas corpus dismissed; detention order upheld as valid, with DM applying mind and grounds relevant.

key_quotes.text: "the District Magistrate had not applied his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and there was complete absence of material"
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Core petitioner argument on non-application of mind, rejected by court.

key_quotes.text: "membership of that party was not per se illegal and the order of detention of the petitioner cannot be legally based upon this ground."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Petitioner contention on irrelevance of party membership, distinguished by court.

key_quotes.text: "the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant consideration... This ground has close and proximate connection"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's holding on relevance of political affiliation.

key_quotes.text: "the petitioner has not made out a case for the grant of a writ under Art. 32."
key_quotes.speaker: court
